question: Question_01_(a)
sols:
We can be a bit clever and factor $x^2-3x-4 = (x-4)(x+1)$ then factor
$x-4$ as a difference of squares where we think of $x$ as the square of
$\sqrt{x}$.

Hence

\begin{align*}x-4  = (\sqrt{x}-2)(\sqrt{x}+2).\end{align*}

Combining gives

\begin{align*}
\lim_{x\rightarrow 4} \frac{x^2-3x-4}{\sqrt{x}-2} &= \lim_{x\rightarrow 4} \frac{(x-4)(x+1)}{\sqrt{x}-2}\\
&=\lim_{x\rightarrow 4} \frac{(\sqrt{x}-2)(\sqrt{x}+2)(x+1)}{\sqrt{x}-2}\\
&=\lim_{x\rightarrow 4} (\sqrt{x}+2)(x+1)\\
&=(\sqrt{4}+2)(4+1)\\
&=20\end{align*}
hints: How can we use conjugates to deal with the square root in the bottom?
